What is the price to be paid for building an utopia? And how thin is the line that separates scuh utopia from a dystopia? America, 1912, while Europe sees itself at the brink of a Total war, the United States of America sees its power rising beyond all the expectatives from the Old World. The future is bright, and the choosen people is close to receive from God what is rightfully theirs. Columbia is the apex symbol of this new world. A city floating high among the clouds, near God himself, free of all the sins that wreck havock upon the Sodoma below. 
But, as well as the USA, upon how many lies, deaths and slaves was Columbia built? Behind the paradise, what kind of hell lies hidden? Much more than a shooter, a "save the princess" and an adventure, Bioshock Infinite is a historical reflection upon the pilars that sustains the modern day US of A.
You're Booker DeWitt, former US soldier and a Pinkerton agent. Indebted to the wrong people, you receive a simple yet strange bargain: "Bring us the girl and wipe away the debt". Who is this girl, the beautifull and lonely princess locked in a tower in the city of Columbia, whose powers can open gaps among worlds? Doesn't really matter, provide she is free by the end of the day. But, at certain point of the game, you will start asking yourself: "Am I really free?" "What is the point of granting physical freedom for her, when our whole lifes are a cage?" "I'm rather be free as a bird, or have the safety of a cage?".
Like an equation, Bioshock Infinite works with constans and variables, and it's up to you to find what is what and who is who inside the vicious world of Columbia.

With all the hype that surrounded this game upon it's release, I expected it to be one of the highest quality games I've played. In all honesty, that is what I got. BioShock Infinite is well-polished, brilliantly presented, and encapsulates the player in it's phenominal storytelling. Its riveting tale of morales and justice along with high-action gameplay often made me catch myself smiling. While BioShock Infinite does properly follow a story arch, filled with intense rising action to an unforgettable climax, no room is left for any sort of falling action or afterstory, but that will probably be left for the DLC.

Presentation: 9.5/10
Gameplay: 9/10
Plot: 8/10

Ce jeu est une véritable réussite. 
Autant au niveau de l'ambiance que de l'histoire et du gameplay.

L'ambiance, si efficace dans Bioshock premier du nom, réussit ici à nous apporter quelque chose de nouveau, d'original et dont le principal atout est d'inviter au voyage. Un voyage au sein d'une dystopie déroutante, angoissante qui tend à l'horreur sous une façade nette et sans bavure.

L'histoire est agréable et se laisse déguster au fil de quelques 25 heures. Les personnages sont bien travaillés et une richesse englobe l'ensemble.

Le gameplay est très bon et on altèrne les phases de découvertes à celles de combats intenses. Seul petit bémol à mon sens: les boss qui ne sont pas forcément extraordinaires.

Enfin, un soin tout particulier a été apporté au travail des détails et c'est là un point des plus agréables.

Un ensemble qui fait de Bioshock Infinite un très bon jeu que je recommande vivement.

Bioshock Infinite was one of the best shooters which I had the pleasure of playing. The game has an amazing story, which some can say that it is not as good as the first one, but it is still a blowing-mind story with strong (and sometimes funny) characters and rich details. The game art direction is incredible with beautiful incredible design in each part of the game, the characters, the buildings, the enemies, everything. The gameplay is incredible, and it is hard to be described. The tears, the vigour, the skyline, everything gives the player a really pleasant and different experience on action FPS. I believe most fans of Bioshock will enjoy this game.
The best Shooter ever when you like story!

I do not often have time to play video games anymore. This game was well worth the time I spent on it.  While it had some stuff that was not the best, it was an overall great game.  I felt it had a good plot line and story. I would definitly recommend the game to anyone.

You are Booker who is sent on a mission to rescue a girl called Elizabeth from Columbia, a flying city with an atmosphere that instantly charms you and makes you want to live there. Now that quickly changes and the situation turns sour. The combat takes it's cue from BioShock and BioShock 2 to reintroduce Plasmids and eve as Vigors and salts, now there are allot of variety in Vigors but are just a clear cut copy of Plasmids and you might be only sticking to one or two Vigors because the rest will probably seem under-powered. A two gun limit is one of the worst things in BioShock Infinite because you'll be trying out a weapon for about 5 seconds and then realize that it is very alike to your previous gun, depending on your play style you'll be sticking to two weapons for the whole game, if you can help it (my favorite are the shotgun and the hand cannon). The game is amazing but I completed it in about 8 hours and I was craving for more, I had mixed feelings about the ending for obvious reasons. But the best things for me are Elizabeth and her chemistry with Booker, she would throw Booker money, health or ammo when he needs it and can provide things like hookshots, turrets, and ammo stations. Another great thing is the skyhook, you can fly around the city on rails reminiscent of Ratchet and Clank but multiplied by 10, trust me you'll know when you try it. *Disclaimer a light spoiler ahead, if you don't want the fucking badass of the game revealed to you then read the message in caps to get a basic message of what it's about then skip to the location with the * beside them* BADASS SONGBIRD IS A FUCKING BADASS, YOU DO NOT FUCK WITH SONGBIRD, SONGBIRD FUCKS YOU. Songbird is a gigantic robotic bird that was Elizabeth's caretaker (bringing her food and drink and books to read) but also not allowing her to leave, and trust me you cannot fight the bird in the game which is disappointing for me, I wished we could have fought it when it is first revealed and it purposely kicking your ass so you know not to fuck with it, *MASSIVE SPOILER AHEAD* when it dies you respect it for caring for Elizabeth and knowing that a badass has fallen, but it loses points for it being under the control of Comstock the whole time which put's it's love and protectiveness for Elizabeth into question *SPOILERS END* The multiple twists are explained nicely and the amount of backstory in the form of voxophones is typical for a BioShock game.


Overall the game is so close to being a masterpiece but it falls just short, but it is still a truly amazing game that YOU need to buy it, I give it a 9/10.

To be honest, I had not been interested in buying Bioshock: Infinite as I didn't play the first 2 games but in the recent Fall Sales,  I tought I got it for a fair price of 7.49$. Later on, while playing the game, I found it quite good but the story became better and more important to me near the end. The end totally blew me away. One of the best ends of a videogame. I'm thinking now what it would've been if I knew the story of Bioshock I & II before Infinite. It probably would've nailed me to a bread crumb with peanut butter on it.

9.7/10

If you like games where there's an amazing world (if you have the rendering muscle) you'll probably like this game. If you're looking for a game that rewards your mental sentiment or a game that even gives you a choice in the end; look elsewhere. My favorite BioShock is the first one. It had the right ballance of puzzles (hacking mini games) action ("zap'em then whack'em!) the right amount of plot twists ("Would you kindly") the right amount of philosophy (worlds grity, you don't get to choose how you start but in the end you're what you make of yourself) So, my recomendation: meh. I could go on about rewarding failure but this is much much better than BioShock 2 (seriously, no backtracking!?)

Seriously the *best* game I own on steam.  I don't really note too much on graphics when I talk about how good a game is, but this is the best looking game I think i've seen in this generation of games.  Beautiful environments, story telling that's remniscent of Bioshock 1 in that it doesn't fuck you with exposition, Elizabeth is a fantastic companion, you never have to do a stupid escort mission (...plus she's a babe).  

One of the downsides to this game compared to the first two Bioshock titles is that you can only have two guns equipped at the same time and that's pretty annoying, but honestly, I overlook that, because the rest of this game is so damn good that it doesn't matter.

You can wait for it to go on sale to get it for cheap, but I'm happy that I spent $60 on this beauty.  It's worth every fucking penny. 100/100 Five Stars 10/10 would play again.
Good story and gameplay i really reccomend i even have it for ps3! *i preorderd*

O jogo possui uma história bem elaborada, mas linear, e em alguns pontos tu nao pode voltar e concluir alguns quests opcionais. Apesar disso ele consegue te manter a par do que acontece do desenrolar da trama. Em tese eu achei o jogo meio facil e significantemente não tão longo, acredito que em poucos dias eu terminei ele. Alguns perks ou poderes que tu encontra acabam nem sendo usados por ser um pouco insignificantes. Em tese eu diria que o Bioshock 1 e 2 são melhores que o Infinite, mas o jogo possui jogabilidade e graficos bons. Achei legal a questão da "fenda" e também o final é surpreendente. 

No meu ver não vale a pena comprar pelo preço de R$89.99, mas recomendo comprar em promoção, como qual eu o fiz, com desconto de 75%, saindo por R$22.49

Incredible. I love almost everything about this game: great story, gameplay, and graphics. I has a little low replay value, but one 15-20 hour playthrough is like ecstasy. Infinite is one of my favorite games ever; I would reccommend this game to ANYONE. It is worthy of the Bioshock franchise.

if you dont own this game. there is something wrong with you

*Warning contain spoilers*The game was really beautiful and enjoyed it most of the time, but then came all the the disappointments like the biggest one for me was without a doubt that you where not able to get a boss fight with song bird and why where there not more interaction with Booker and Elisabeth(like the combination of their powers showed in earlier gameplay videos) and the npc's. Only cutscenes with songbird most of the time. They should have made interactions aviable in the cutscenes like many modern games do now a day,  Where was all the nice stuff we saw in 10 and 11? There should also have been more types of enemies and sadly many of them looked very similar*sighs* The rail system should have been like the gameplay videos showed in 2010. That would have made more sense. 

But to say the least I enjoyed most of the game. The graphics do get 10/10 and so does the soundtrack as well as game with almost no really noticeable bugs. So if your looking for a visual stunning experience and a great flowing game you should try it out. 

In the end it's a great game but since it does not deliver all the things I looked for this game only get's a 6/10 from me.
Gunplay is terrible for a PC game.

Game play is similar to the first Bioshock but was made somewhat easier by including a companion to throw you things you need.  What marred this game completely is the story itself.  The writer has the subtley of a sledgehammer for the point of view on history and politics.  The ending was something akin to Primer with all the back-n-forth in the story and left me completely unsatisfied when I was done.  I felt good after I finished Bioshock this game with its amatuer theatrics and story left me feeling frustrated, even empty inside.  

Skip this game, if it's 5 bucks then maybe but only if you have a need to see some cool graphics otherwise get one of the Farcry games or Crysis.

Bioshock Infinite really sets a new high for first person shooters - fitting really, considering its set in Columbia, a floating metropolis above the clouds. With Infinite, original Bioshock developer Irrational has changed the game, they have not attempted to transport the gunplay and atmosphere of a city at the bottom of the sea to one that literally floats to the heavens, and while there are some call-backs to the first game and both are indeed first person shooters, Bioshock Infinite is a fresh experience once again delivered in a stunning original world whose first moments may just illicit the same awe we all got on our first view of the failed utopia of Rapture
